g.text: value for the sample doped with 100%Eu
The emission stability of the phosphor at elevated temperatures is an important factor determining
the phosphors suitability for practical applications. The high power near-UV or blue LEDs can heat up
C; therefore, the phosphor considered for such application should emit
ciently. Besides, the temperature-dependent integrated emission spectra can
also be used to determine the thermal quenching
(this value shows the temperature at which
phosphor loses half of its e
ciency) and thermal quenching activation energy
are the temperature-dependent emission integral andthe highest value of emission
can be derived by slight changes of equation 3 [
c). These results demonstrate that Rb
ciency at temperatures well above of the typical high power LED; therefore,
it could be applied as a red component in near-UV based white LEDs. Besides, the
) sample are also higher than those reported for its potassium counterpart
) is superior if compared to K
The temperature-dependent PL decay curves were also recorded for Rb
. The PL decay proﬁle was single exponential and the PL lifetime
values were calculated employing equation 2. The obtained temperature-dependent PL lifetime values
for those three specimens are depicted in Figure
d. The exact PL lifetime values together with standard
deviations are summarized in Table S3. It is interesting to note that PL lifetime values of samples
decreases with increasing temperature. However, the PL lifetime values
increases up to 400 K and only then start to decrease. This shows,
ciency of this phosphor is the highest at 400 K.
